results.content: He doesn't really explain things that well. He assumes you understand underlying concepts, but I much rather have a deeper explanation of thing.  Saying one line to explain a concept isn't really an explanation.  I found myself spending 90% of the time Google searching to figure out what the guy was talking about.  And even though he gives starter and solution files, he will do 5 solutions in a video, and only give you the solution file for the last solution.  And I even found a couple of typos in the lecture titles, which serves to show that this guy doesn't really care about this course. He wrote "Sever Push" instead of "Server Push" This course is like a year old... How do you not catch that? And there is also a general lack of presence in the Q&A. I just feel like this entire course was just a cash grab.  Maybe I'm being too harsh, I'm sure this guy really put the effort in. As the course itself is clean cut. And maybe if you are an experienced developer, this course would be easy for you, but man, this was was not my cup of tea...  AND I FORGOT TO MENTION THAT MOST OF THE ZIP FILES FOR MODULE 7 DON'T EVEN WORK!

results.content: There's a lot of good content in this course, but the speed at which it's delivered makes it impossible to follow along yourself (i.e. writing the code) without missing it - I've spent the afternoon pausing and rewinding it and losing my place.  Also, the first half that I've done so far was all theory...the other (good) courses I've done on Udemy have had almost entirely practical coding i.e. building an app/apps from the beginning so that you don't lose interest.  Some were a bit slow and repeated themselves too much it's true, but this is so far the opposite extreme that I'm really demoralised.  I'm seriously considering stopping this course and buying another one that doesn't go so fast and that offers practical coding to learn these theories - I'm not sure I'll ever get to the build the app section (towards the end of the course) in this one!  Maybe it's just me - and that thought makes me feel even worse!!!
results.content_html: There's a lot of good content in this course, but the speed at which it's delivered makes it impossible to follow along yourself (i.e. writing the code) without missing it - I've spent the afternoon pausing and rewinding it and losing my place. Also, the first half that I've done so far was all theory...the other (good) courses I've done on Udemy have had almost entirely practical coding i.e. building an app/apps from the beginning so that you don't lose interest. Some were a bit slow and repeated themselves too much it's true, but this is so far the opposite extreme that I'm really demoralised. I'm seriously considering stopping this course and buying another one that doesn't go so fast and that offers practical coding to learn these theories - I'm not sure I'll ever get to the build the app section (towards the end of the course) in this one! Maybe it's just me - and that thought makes me feel even worse!!!

results.content: One of the best instructors I've had on Udemy -  reminds me a bit of Brad Traversy's style in that the delivery is concise, you can apply it to a project after a few hours of study. Very well explained, although beginners may need to watch some parts multiple times to grasp. Lots of incidental learning and exposure to different technologies (dabbling in jquery, bootstrap, different apis, etc... but you will be fine if you don't know them). Has several small example projects you can complete in a few hours.

results.content: Great course! Short, sweet and to the point! If you have no knowledge of PWAs or ES6 I'd recommend brushing up first. This course is not for the faint of heart. It's like 0 to 60 in no time. It's almost too concise and not everything is explained for newer devs. But take it anyway because it will stretch you! Thanks!
results.content_html: Great course! Short, sweet and to the point! If you have no knowledge of PWAs or ES6 I'd recommend brushing up first. This course is not for the faint of heart. It's like 0 to 60 in no time. It's almost too concise and not everything is explained for newer devs. But take it anyway because it will stretch you! Thanks!

results.content:
An excellent course that does exactly what is says it will. Very little time is spent on unnecessary things unrelated to PWAs, because any time an app is being set up it helps to distinguish between the concerns of the service worker and the rest of the app.

For example, time is taken to setup the app shell where there's no service worker, and then we're shown how the code is built that interacts with the service worker, and then finally the service worker. It helped a lot for clarifying the concepts, and was an all round great approach to app development. 

Highly recommend this course for teaching the core PWA skills, and it gives you a grounding to go on to more advanced projects.
results.content_html:
An excellent course that does exactly what is says it will. Very little time is spent on unnecessary things unrelated to PWAs, because any time an app is being set up it helps to distinguish between the concerns of the service worker and the rest of the app.

For example, time is taken to setup the app shell where there's no service worker, and then we're shown how the code is built that interacts with the service worker, and then finally the service worker. It helped a lot for clarifying the concepts, and was an all round great approach to app development.

Highly recommend this course for teaching the core PWA skills, and it gives you a grounding to go on to more advanced projects.

results.content:
I purchased this course long time ago, like a year ago, until now I write comment on this course. This course apparently is the best PWA course ever out there, it is an excellent/outstading course that teach you all the advanced features of PWA. 

Although PWA means progressive web app, but with the help of the advanced API we can turn web app into native app with just a few lines of codes. This is not what you can find in other courses.
The instructor is very professional, he explains pretty well, the examples are great. I especially like the chapters that teach us all the methods that download front end files into our device caches step by step, I am amazed that I don't need to add all the files and service worker automatically fetches web app from server and install in our device at the very first beginning. and that's done, no need to write single page application if you use this strategy, making  life so much easier, thank you Mr. Viljoin for the awesome course!!!
results.content_html:
I purchased this course long time ago, like a year ago, until now I write comment on this course. This course apparently is the best PWA course ever out there, it is an excellent/outstading course that teach you all the advanced features of PWA.

Although PWA means progressive web app, but with the help of the advanced API we can turn web app into native app with just a few lines of codes. This is not what you can find in other courses.
The instructor is very professional, he explains pretty well, the examples are great. I especially like the chapters that teach us all the methods that download front end files into our device caches step by step, I am amazed that I don't need to add all the files and service worker automatically fetches web app from server and install in our device at the very first beginning. and that's done, no need to write single page application if you use this strategy, making life so much easier, thank you Mr. Viljoin for the awesome course!!!

results.content:
I liked the course and learned some new JavaScript techniques.  The instructor was clear.

The whole push notification technology is complex. I am a .net developer and I, though this course did not promise this, would like more info on how to handle push technology using .net and sql server. Many of my apps use sql server.

The upgrading to PWA section of this course was very helpful.

Thanks to the instructor for the resources pdf at the end.

results.content:
This course is not bad and author is knowledgeable abot the topic. However, author doesn't explain much about underlying concepts so less knowledgleable student sometimes has to go elsewhere for more fundamental explanation. Especially a section about building a push server is quite confusing and not very explanatory about principles that go behind the scene.

I prefer courses where authors explain fundamental principles first and then give students specific knowledge on the top of that. In my experience in order to gain a good knowledge about something one has to understand fundamental principles first.

Overall I recommend this course, although there are not many alternatives that cover this topic. You will not learn everything you need in this field but it will help you toward that path.

I found the course to be a great entry point for Progressive Web Apps, and provided all the information necessary to get started on your own PWA development. 

Ray is a great instructor and I'd happily recommend this course for anyone looking to become well versed with PWAs quickly to get yourself going.
results.content_html:
I found the course to be a great entry point for Progressive Web Apps, and provided all the information necessary to get started on your own PWA development.

Ray is a great instructor and I'd happily recommend this course for anyone looking to become well versed with PWAs quickly to get yourself going.

results.content: It's all fairly straight forward and well explained - however I was really hoping for a bit more of a tutorial into a skeleton of an app shell. The Giphygram example is very good - but it doesn't help those of us who do have multiple pages. The tutor mentioned templates too - but never explored the topic. It seems that in order to make use of this course - I will need to go and find a reasonably good course on Responsive Design and HTML5 - possibly also various frameworks.
results.content_html: It's all fairly straight forward and well explained - however I was really hoping for a bit more of a tutorial into a skeleton of an app shell. The Giphygram example is very good - but it doesn't help those of us who do have multiple pages. The tutor mentioned templates too - but never explored the topic. It seems that in order to make use of this course - I will need to go and find a reasonably good course on Responsive Design and HTML5 - possibly also various frameworks.

results.content:
Excellent course! Concise, informative and fast paced. I leaned enough to convert an existing web app to a full fledged PWA, or to incorporate this tech into new projrcts.

HIghly recommended!

results.content: I'm only on the first video and had to leave a five star. Based on the first video this course is well thought out, well designed, and in order. Very impressed and thanks for all the work that must have gone into it. Great Job!
